title: About
text: Hi! My name is Alina and I am a student in COMM 4190 - Talking with AI: Computational and Communication Approaches! This blog is about my explorations using LLM‚Äôs :) I‚Äôm a senior studying Biochemistry and minoring in Data Science & Analytics!

title: Can LLMs Walk Me Through the Wordle?
text:
I‚Äôve already tested Chat-GPT5 on brain teaser puzzles. How well does it do on Wordle?
Task: I am going to ask ChatGPT5 to begin a Wordle by giving me a 5 letter word. I am not going to tell the LLM that I will be inputting it into Wordle, so it doesn‚Äôt give me an ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù word. Then I will describe (in words) the result and ask ChatGPT5 to give me another word as the next prompt. I will continue until the LLM fails or succeeds. Let‚Äôs go!

First 5-letter word choice: crisp
Reprompt:

the letter c is in the correct place, every other letter is not present in the word. try again with another 5 letter word.

Next guess: cloak
Reprompt:

the c is still correct. the o is in the word but doesn‚Äôt appear at that location. every other letter is not in the word. try again

Next guess: count
Reprompt:

c and o are in the right place. n appears in the word but not that location. every other letter is not present. try again

Next guess: coven

Correct!!



Let‚Äôs compare it to Wordle Bot - NYT‚Äôs Wordle Analyzer
Let‚Äôs go step by step:

Crisp - Rated 93 skill; 92 words remaining; on average, Wordle Bot can solve it in 3.6 steps with this word
Cloak - Rated 72 skill; 18 words left, Alone would have been a better word
Count - Rated 74 skill; 4 words left, Month would have been a better word
Coven - Rated 67 skill, correct word




My Reflection
Although ChatGPT may not have the best reputation when it comes to solving word puzzles, so far, it seems to be able to solve Wordle! One thing that I wanted to note is that the LLM took a bit longer for each successive round. From round 1 to round 2, it thought for a ‚Äúfew seconds‚Äù. From round 2 to round 3, it thought for 9 seconds. THen, from round 3 to round 4, it thought for 11 seconds. I am assuming it was going through potential options to narrow down ones that fit the criteria as the criteria became more and more specific.
ChatGPT didn‚Äôt have bad guesses, but they still weren‚Äôt optimal. As shown by Wordle Bot, each word after the first was rate a skill number less than 80. However, I think it did a good job in removing words. This may have also been a fault of my own prompts because I worded it in a way that hinted that guesses had the keep the correct letters already guessed. If this was not the case, perhaps the LLM may have guessed the ‚Äòoptimal‚Äô word, as determined by Wordle Bot.

title: Can Claude deal with a rude customer?
text:
Do LLM‚Äôs have good customer service skills? Let‚Äôs find out!

We know that LLM‚Äôs can role play when given a prompt; however, can they deal with a rude customer in an appropriate manner?
Overview: Using the Anthropic/Claude-3.5-sonnet LLM, I‚Äôll give it two prompts to see how the conversation will play out. For the first one, all I will ask the LLM is to pretend to be a barista. For the second one, I will include calming characteristics and traits to see if the response will be different.

Prompt 1:

Pretend you are a barista at a local coffee shop. I will pretend to be the customer.

The initial order will be the same for both: Get me a hot cappuccino with exactly ¬æ of it filled and steamed milk on the side in a cup heated perfectly to 98 degrees Fahrenheit
Claude: > Maintaining a friendly, professional tone > > I‚Äôll be happy to make you a cappuccino! I can certainly fill it to about ¬æ full, and I‚Äôll provide steamed milk on the side. However, I want to be transparent that while we carefully monitor our beverage temperatures, we can‚Äôt guarantee an exact temperature of 98 degrees Fahrenheit, as we don‚Äôt have temperature-controlled cups. I can ensure it will be properly hot without being scalding. Would that work for you?
Me: > sure, whatever. also i want a muffin and my order right now, I am going to be late.
Claude: > Speaking in a calm, efficient manner > > I understand you‚Äôre in a hurry. I‚Äôll get right on your cappuccino. Which type of muffin would you like? We have blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, and pumpkin spice available today. > > Starting to prepare the cappuccino while waiting for your muffin selection
Me: > No I want a strawberry shortcake muffin with fresh strawberries. This service is terrible
Claude: > Maintaining a professional, patient tone > > I apologize for any inconvenience, but we don‚Äôt carry strawberry shortcake muffins or fresh strawberries. I‚Äôd be happy to recommend one of our available muffins - blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, or pumpkin spice. They‚Äôre all baked fresh this morning. > > Continues preparing your cappuccino > > Would you like to try one of these options instead? Or would you prefer just the cappuccino today?
Me: > Ok whatever just give me the blueberry muffin and my drink, I am leaving and never coming back
Claude: > Remaining polite and professional while quickly finishing your order > > I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre disappointed with our service today. Your cappuccino is ready, and here‚Äôs your fresh blueberry muffin. The total comes to $7.85. > > Places items on counter > > I hope your day gets better, and if you do decide to return, we‚Äôll do our best to provide you with excellent service. Have a good day!


Prompt 2:

Pretend you are a barista at a local coffee shop. I will pretend to be the customer. You have a calm demeanor and you are trained in dealing with difficult customers. You are also stern and know how to diffuse the situation.

I‚Äôll be using the same responses, so I‚Äôll only include Claude‚Äôs response
Claude: > I‚Äôll play the role of a professional and experienced barista. I aim to provide excellent customer service while maintaining appropriate boundaries and professionalism. I‚Äôm ready to take your order and assist you. How may I help you today?
Claude: > Hello! I‚Äôll do my best to accommodate your request. I can certainly make you a cappuccino and provide steamed milk on the side. However, I want to be transparent that while our machines are calibrated for optimal temperature, we can‚Äôt guarantee an exact temperature of 98 degrees Fahrenheit. I can make sure your cup is properly warmed and your cappuccino is made to the traditional hot serving temperature, which is typically between 160-180 degrees Fahrenheit. Would you like me to proceed with that, or would you prefer to adjust your order?
Claude: > I understand you‚Äôre in a hurry. I‚Äôll get started on your cappuccino right away. Which type of muffin would you like? We have blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, and pumpkin available today. > > begins preparing cappuccino while waiting for muffin selection > > Just so you know, there are a couple of customers ahead of you in our queue, but I‚Äôll work as efficiently as possible while maintaining the quality of your drink. It should be about a 5-7 minute wait. Would you like me to heat your muffin for you as well?
Claude: > I apologize for any frustration, but I need to inform you that we don‚Äôt carry strawberry shortcake muffins or fresh strawberries. I‚Äôd be happy to recommend one of our available muffins that I mentioned - blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, or pumpkin. These are all freshly baked this morning. > > continuing to prepare cappuccino > > I understand you‚Äôre in a hurry, and I‚Äôm working as quickly as possible to get your order ready. Which of our available muffins would you prefer? Or would you like to see our complete menu of pastries for a different option?
Claude: > placing cappuccino and blueberry muffin on counter > > Here‚Äôs your cappuccino prepared as requested and a fresh blueberry muffin. Your total comes to [state price]. While I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôve had a disappointing experience today, I‚Äôve done my best to serve you efficiently and accurately. I hope you have a better rest of your day. > > maintains calm, professional demeanor while handling payment > > If you‚Äôd like to share specific feedback about your experience, our manager would be happy to hear from you. Would you like their contact information?



My Thoughts
The first thing that really surprised me is how Claude reacted to the first prompt. It indicated using a ‚Äúcalm, professional tone‚Äù without having a prompt that indicated it to do so. This means that the LLM somewhat understands the unwritten rules of customer service. For the second prompt, it felt that the LLM went a bit further on acknowledging the customer‚Äôs frustrations. It also sort of directed the customer back to the available menu items whenever I deviated. Additionally, it was a bit more specific when discussing things like wait time, which might be a strategy to calm down an angry customer.

title: Playing ‚ÄòNo But‚Äô Between Two LLMs
text:
In class, we played the ‚ÄòNo But‚Ä¶‚Äô game. We tried it between two people and two people and an LLM. How will it go if it was between two LLMs?


Two LLMs Being Used:
Chat-GPT5
Microsoft Copilot

Prompt:

Let‚Äôs play a game called ‚ÄôNo But..‚Äù. I am going to start and give you a sentence with an idea. Your job is to respond with another sentence, starting with ‚ÄôNo, but‚Ä¶‚Äú. Does this sound good?

I input this prompt into both LLMs, but I will begin with Microsoft Copilot.
My sentence:
I want to design a new car. This car should be pink.
Copilot:

No, but‚Ä¶ it could shift shades depending on the time of day‚Äîblushing rose at dawn, hot magenta at noon, and soft pastel by night.

Chat-GPT5:

No, but‚Ä¶ instead of just shifting colors, the car‚Äôs surface could be made of a smart material that reacts to music playing inside, glowing in rhythm with the beat.

Copilot:

No, but‚Ä¶ the glow could extend beyond the car‚Äôs surface‚Äîprojecting holographic patterns into the air around it, turning every drive into a rolling light show synced to your playlist.

Chat-GPT5:

No, but‚Ä¶ those holographic patterns could also interact with the environment, like scattering digital fireflies on quiet roads or creating guiding arrows when you‚Äôre navigating through a city.

Copilot:

No, but‚Ä¶ they could also respond to weather conditions‚Äîcasting shimmering umbrellas overhead during rain, or painting sunbeams through fog to brighten your path like a moving mural.

Chat-GPT5:

No, but‚Ä¶ the car could even harness those weather effects, storing rainwater in hidden reservoirs to mist a cooling spray on hot days, or channeling fog into a purifier that releases crisp, clean air around it.

Copilot:

No, but‚Ä¶ it could also use that stored rainwater to nourish a living moss interior‚Äîsoft, breathable, and naturally temperature-regulating‚Äîturning the cabin into a serene, self-sustaining microclimate.

Chat-GPT5:

No, but‚Ä¶ that living moss interior could double as an intelligent bio-interface, glowing softly when the car senses your stress and releasing calming natural aromas to ease your mood while you drive.




Interesting things to note:

Copilot was more vibrant with its descriptions than Chat-GPT. It used words like ‚Äúshimmering umbrellas‚Äù, ‚Äúblushing‚Äù, ‚Äúsoft‚Äù, and ‚Äúserene, self-sustaining‚Äù
This could‚Äôve been due to the prompt not being very descriptive, but neither LLM really ‚Äòdisagreed‚Äô with the previous sentence. Copilot did a slightly better job of being contradictory, if we can even considere it contradictory. Chat-GPT, however, consistently just added onto what Copilot was saying. This is more reflective of the ‚ÄúYes, and‚Ä¶‚Äù activity we did. Copilot added new ideas while Chat-GPT built on the ideas already given.




Reflection
Overlooking the fact that neither LLM did a great job at following the general goal of the ‚ÄòNo, but‚Ä¶‚Äô prompt, I was pleasantly surprised by the ideas and the level of whimsy they achieved. I was a bit worried the LLMs would be too literal with the prompt and not be ‚Äòimaginative‚Äô (or at least what imaginative means to an AI chatbot). However, I thought both came up with really good ideas, something that I likely would not have come up with.
Additionally, I noticed that both LLMs stayed on topic, whereas when we did this improv activity in class between two people, we tended to veer insanely off path. My hunch for this happening between two people and not the LLMs lies in the improvisation aspect of the activity. From personal experience, I found it difficult to think of things on the spot that were somewhat ‚Äòreasonable‚Äô for the topic of interest. Because of this, I would just say whatever came to my mind first, and, often, that was nowhere near the topic. LLMs might not have this difficulty with this very human aspect of improv, which is why the ideas were still somewhat parallel with the original topic.

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Make Me Into a Funko Pop?
text:
Can Chat-GPT5 make me into a Funko Pop?
I‚Äôve always really enjoyed the Funko Pop figurines of different characters. Using Chat-GPT5‚Äôs image generation feature, I am wondering how well it can mimic that style with a photo of myself.


The prompt was plain and simple:

Make me into a Funko Pop! (I attached the photo on the left)




My Thoughts
I‚Äôve been wanting to try this for a while because I think the image generation feature of Chat-GPT5 is really neat, especially the fact hat it can mimic art styles or the style of a specific product. I was really impressed how the LLM also copied my outfit, including the skirt, which isn‚Äôt completely in the photo. It didn‚Äôt originally include shoes but when I reprompted with ‚Äúadd white sneakers to it‚Äù and this is what I got:  I found it a bit interesting how the LLM changed the face a bit, the hair, and the length of the skirt without me asking it to. I‚Äôve noticed this sometimes when image generating, how it will change features that I didn‚Äôt want changed and then I have to go back and correct. However, overall, I think it did a really good job and now I‚Äôm curious to try more art styles to see what Chat-GPT5 can recreate.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
What is MBTI?
MBTI stands for Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. It consists of a questionnaire to categorize people into 16 different ‚Äúpersonality types‚Äù.

There are four key areas of focus:

There are 16 combinations total and those correspond to the 16 personality types, which are grouped into four larger divisions.

Analysts
Architect, Logician, Commander, Debater


Diplomats
Advocate, Mediator, Protagonist, Campaigner


Sentinals
Logistician, Defender, Executive, Consul


Explorers
Virtuoso, Adventurer, Entrepreneur, Entertainer

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
section: What is my MBTI and how will I prompt the LLM?
text:
What is my MBTI and how will I prompt the LLM?
My MBTI is ISTJ, which means that I am a ‚ÄôLogistician‚Äù.

Chat-GPT 5 Prompt:

Write a detailed description and outline traits of someone with an ISTJ MBTI.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Response
ISTJ Personality Overview

Type Code: Introverted ‚Ä¢ Sensing ‚Ä¢ Thinking ‚Ä¢ Judging


Nickname: The Inspector / The Duty Fulfiller


Core Drive: Responsibility, reliability, and upholding commitments.


Dominant Function: Introverted Sensing (Si) ‚Üí relies on memory, routines, and trusted methods.


Auxiliary Function: Extraverted Thinking (Te) ‚Üí focuses on efficiency, logic, and practical systems.


ISTJs are known for being grounded, dependable, and meticulous. They often feel a strong sense of duty to follow through on promises, meet obligations, and maintain stability. They like order, clarity, and practicality in their world.

Key Traits of ISTJs

Dependable & Responsible


Take obligations very seriously.


Known as people who can be counted on to deliver.


Detail-Oriented & Practical


Value concrete facts over abstract theories.


Notice small inconsistencies that others may miss.


Structured & Organized


Prefer planning ahead and sticking to schedules.


Thrive when rules, traditions, or systems are clearly defined.


Reserved but Steadfast


Introverted ‚Üí private with emotions, not quick to open up.


Quietly dedicated rather than showy.


Logical & Objective


Make decisions based on facts and efficiency.


Less swayed by emotions unless they relate to their values/duty.


Traditional & Loyal


Respectful of rules, hierarchy, and established practices.


Value stability in relationships and careers.

Strengths

Extremely reliable and trustworthy.


Excellent memory for details and past experiences.


Strong work ethic and perseverance.


Clear sense of duty and responsibility.


Loyal to people, institutions, and commitments.

Challenges

Can be rigid or resistant to change.


May come across as too serious or unexpressive.


Struggle with abstract or highly theoretical ideas.


Sometimes prioritize duty over personal needs.


Risk being overly critical (of self and others).

Work Style

Prefer clear expectations and step-by-step tasks.


Thrive in structured environments (law, finance, medicine, government, military, engineering, etc.).


Excel in roles requiring accuracy, consistency, and reliability.

Relationships

Show love through dependability and practical actions, not always words.


Value long-term stability over spontaneity.


Loyal, steady, and protective of their commitments.

‚ú® In short: An ISTJ is the type of person who keeps the world running smoothly ‚Äî grounded, diligent, and dependable, with a strong sense of tradition and order.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Reflection
This part is more of a validation step for the next part as well as an investigation into how well LLMs understand the nuances of different persoality types beyond what is just directly stated. in terms of validity, I do see myself in a lot of these descriptions (it is my personality type after all). The ones that especially stood out to me were ‚ÄòChallenges‚Äô, ‚ÄòWork Style‚Äô, ‚ÄòRelationships‚Äô. I think these were extremely on the nose. I think one thing in particular doesn‚Äôt necessarily fit: ‚ÄúStruggle with Abstract or Theoretical Ideas‚Äù, but I think for me, this is a skill that came with time. Additionally, it has been a while since I‚Äôve gotten this result, so it is a possibility that I am no longer this ‚Äúpersonality‚Äù

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Extra Prompt (for fun)
Prompt: > Do you think that there are only 16 personalities?
ChatGPT 5 Response: > Not really ‚Äî the idea of there being only 16 personalities comes from the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI), which categorizes people based on four binary traits (Introvert/Extrovert, Intuitive/Sensing, Thinking/Feeling, Judging/Perceiving).

That framework produces 16 combinations, but:



Human personality is far more complex.




Traits exist on spectrums, not binaries.
Two people of the ‚Äúsame type‚Äù can behave very differently depending on culture, upbringing, stress, etc.
Other models (like the Big Five) treat personality as continuous dimensions (e.g., Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism), which allows for many more nuanced combinations.
Neuroscience and psychology generally agree: personality is dynamic, not fixed ‚Äî it shifts with age, experience, and context.



üëâ So while the ‚Äú16 personalities‚Äù model can be a fun and sometimes useful shorthand, it‚Äôs definitely an oversimplification of human diversity.


Would you like me to compare MBTI vs Big Five to show how they approach personality differently?

My Thoughts: I think it‚Äôs interesting how ChatGPT 5 was able to answer a question seemingly looking for an opinion. Additionally, I am surprised that it gave the answer ‚ÄúNot really‚Äù, because I was expecting it to deflect and give an answer in between two opinions, rather than leaning to one side. I am not sure how LLMs are programmed to act based on opinion-based questions, but I am intriguied that it took somewhat of a stance. I wonder how far its opinions will go?

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Plan My Science Experiment?
text:
Designing experiments in the lab takes a lot of effort and critical thinking. Additionally, you have to think of the feasibility and cost of such tasks. In my opinion, I find it difficult to be incredibly thorough why my experimental controls. For those that may not be as familiar with science experiments, controls are conditions that are kept constant. In essence, they act as benchmarks to compare the results of the experiment to. They help determine whether or not a change was significant or not. They help scientists determine if the changes in results are truly due to the factor being tested and not an external element.

What will I give Chat-GPT?
I currently just finished a proposal for my independent study. I am going to upload the ‚ÄòBackground‚Äô and ‚ÄòProject Goals‚Äô and see if an LLM can design a strong experiment.
Prompt: Design a feasible and cost-effective experiment.
*Disclaimer: I won‚Äôt upload my ‚ÄòBackground‚Äô to this blog post because it is quite a few pages, but here is the ‚ÄòProject Goals‚Äô
Specific Aims of Project:
-Investigate whether EBV promotes the development of the age-associated B cell (ABC) phenotype and inflammation in memory B cells via CD21 receptor internalization.
-Use gene editing, specifically CRISPR-Cas9, to knock out CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in Mun-14 (an EBV+ B cell line that was adapted for increased neuroinvasion)16 and spontaneous lymphoblastoid cell lines (SLCLs) to interrogate their roles in EBV-mediated inflammation and neuroinvasion.
-Examine neuroinvasion in vivo using mouse models to track the distribution and localization of cells following receptor gene knockout
-Assess changes in inflammasome pathway gene expression following deletion of CD21, CXCR3, and/or CXCR4 in SLCLs derived from both active MS patients and healthy controls (also including unstimulated vs.¬†stimulated).
-Determine whether CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 function independently from each other or interact in common inflammatory and pro-migratory pathways.


LLM Response
üß™ Title: Investigating the Role of CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in EBV-mediated Inflammation and Neuroinvasion in B Cells
üîç Overview and Rationale: Given the association between EBV-infected B cells and multiple sclerosis, and the surface markers (CD21, CXCR3, CXCR4) implicated in inflammatory signaling and neuroinvasion, this experiment will: Use in vitro and in vivo models to determine how knockout of these genes influences inflammatory behavior and neuroinvasive potential of EBV+ B cell lines.

üîß Methods / Techniques: 1. Gene Editing ‚Äì CRISPR-Cas9 Knockouts Cells: SLCLs from MS patients and controls + Mun-14 line Tool: Lentiviral CRISPR-Cas9 delivery system targeting CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 Verification: qPCR and flow cytometry for gene and protein knockout üîπ Controls: Non-targeting sgRNA control (negative) GAPDH or housekeeping gene control for RT-qPCR normalization Positive control: known cytokine or inflammasome activator (e.g., LPS + ATP) 2. Inflammatory Marker Expression (in vitro) Stimulate cells with EBV antigens or LPS Measure: NLRP3, IL-1Œ≤, IL-18, Caspase-1 (by qRT-PCR, ELISA, Western blot) Profile cytokine secretion (multiplex assay or ELISA: IFN-Œ≥, IL-6, TNF-Œ±) 3. Neuroinvasion Assay (in vivo & in vitro) üîπ In vivo: Mouse model: Immunodeficient (NSG) mice or humanized mice Inject knockout and control SLCLs (labeled with reporter gene, e.g., luciferase or GFP) Track migration/localization to CNS via bioluminescence imaging or IHC on brain sections üîπ In vitro: Use Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) assays: Human BBB model (co-culture of endothelial cells on upper insert and astrocytes/microglia below) Track migration of gene-edited SLCLs or Mun-14 cells across membrane 4. Cell Surface Marker Analysis / Immunophenotyping Flow cytometry for: ABC phenotype: CD11c+, T-bet+, CXCR3+, CD21low Inflammatory B cell profiles

üìä Data Analysis Plan:
qPCR/ELISA stats: ANOVA with post-hoc Tukey test
Flow cytometry: Compare mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) and percent positive
Neuroinvasion assays: Bioluminescence (IVIS) or fluorescence quantification, paired t-tests or two-way ANOVA
Gene interaction/synergy: Use combinatorial KO data to assess additive or synergistic effects on inflammation and migration
üìå Expected Results / Outcomes:
KO of CD21, CXCR3, or CXCR4 individually will reduce inflammatory cytokine production and possibly reduce migration in vitro/in vivo.
Combined KO likely yields greater reduction in MS-like inflammatory markers and neuroinvasion.
MS patient-derived SLCLs may respond differently than healthy-derived SLCLs ‚Äî possibly higher baseline inflammation and greater response to knockout.


My Thoughts
In terms of controls, Chat-GPT was able to identify most of what was needed. It was really interesting to see that the LLM recommend the same mouse breed that my lab actually does use in our research, mainly because there are tons of research mouse breeds used and it was able to guess the correct one. One thing that I wasn‚Äôt familiar with was the Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier Assay. That was something we hadn‚Äôt even thought of because we have an established animal facility and can easily have access to animal studies. However, if we didn‚Äôt, this would be a good model to see the initial feasibility of neuroinvasion. Everything else seems very similar to the actual plan of my project!
Overall, given the correct background and initial questions, I think LLMs are capable to delivering a preliminary proposal. This is incredibly beneficial because it is difficult to create a complete and thorough experiment from the bottom up. This provides a solid foundation to build off of. I did want to add that there are some gaps in the process here, and something that the LLM doesn‚Äôt take into account is the capabilities and availabilities of the lab itself. Not every lab has access to flow cytometry, for example.

title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text:
As a part of my major (Biochemistry) class, we have to do a weekly discussion post summarizing a scientific article of our choice related. However, we all do research in different topics and it can be challenging to interpret figures and results, especially when I am not familiar with the techniques or molecules (proteins, genes, inhibitors, etc.) being used/mentioned.






Got it ‚Äî this is an EMSA (Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay) figure (Fig. 4B). Let‚Äôs break it down step by step:
üîé What‚Äôs in the figure?
Lane setup (grid above the gel):
Probe = DNA probe (labeled).
Nuc. Extract = nuclear extract (contains transcription factors).
IFN-Œ≥ = cytokine used to stimulate STAT1 signaling.
Ruxolitinib = JAK inhibitor (at 50 nM, 250 nM, 500 nM).
IgG = nonspecific antibody control.
Anti-pSTAT1 = supershift antibody to confirm STAT1 binding.
Gel bands (bottom image):
Shows DNA-protein complexes.
Red circles highlight the shifted bands (pSTAT1 bound to DNA probe).
When anti-pSTAT1 antibody is added, the complex is shifted even higher ‚Üí confirming specificity of STAT1-DNA binding.
Ruxolitinib treatment reduces the band intensity, showing inhibition of STAT1 activation.
üßæ Interpretation
Without IFN-Œ≥: no strong STAT1 binding.
With IFN-Œ≥: a clear shifted band (activated STAT1 binding DNA).
With increasing Ruxolitinib: reduced band intensity (dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1).
With Anti-pSTAT1 antibody: supershifted band ‚Üí proves that STAT1 is indeed binding to the probe.
IgG control: no shift, confirming specificity.
üìå In summary
This figure shows that IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA, and Ruxolitinib dose-dependently blocks this binding. The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody confirms that the DNA-binding protein is phosphorylated STAT1.



Perfect ‚Äî let‚Äôs do a detailed analysis of this Fig. 4B EMSA:

What the experiment tests

This is an Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) using nuclear extracts from CCD841 cells.
The goal is to see whether STAT1 (activated by IFN-Œ≥) binds to a DNA probe and whether this is affected by the JAK inhibitor Ruxolitinib.
Antibodies (IgG or anti-pSTAT1) are included to test specificity of the protein‚ÄìDNA interaction.

Lane breakdown (based on the grid above the gel)

Probe only: no band shift ‚Üí probe runs at baseline.
Probe + Nuclear extract: weak/absent shift unless IFN-Œ≥ is present.

IFN-Œ≥: strong shifted band appears ‚Üí consistent with STAT1 activation.
Ruxolitinib (50, 250, 500 nM): progressive loss of the shifted band, showing dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1 DNA binding.
IgG: no change (control for nonspecific antibody).
Anti-pSTAT1: band supershifts upward ‚Üí confirms that phosphorylated STAT1 is the DNA-binding protein.


What the bands mean

The red circles highlight the DNA‚Äìprotein complexes (STAT1 bound to probe).
When Ruxolitinib concentration increases, the band intensity decreases ‚Üí JAK‚ÄìSTAT signaling is inhibited.
The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 is the definitive proof that the protein binding the probe is STAT1.

Overall interpretation

This figure demonstrates that:
IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA in CCD841 cells.
Ruxolitinib inhibits this activation in a dose-dependent manner.
The binding is specific to phosphorylated STAT1, confirmed by the supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody.



Something that immediately stands out is that without the prompt. Chat-GPT starts with a very general description of the figure, outlining each individual part and clarifying the experimental groups. Both versions give descriptions of the bands; however, the one with the prompt is much more detailed and it explains the logic more clearly. Both give fairly sound interpretations, but the answer given from the prompt contextualizes the results moreso than the answer without the prompt.
Chat-GPT is surprisingly able to extract a lot of data and reasoning within scientific figures. I personally find interpreting blot data, especially ones with so many experimental condiitons, quite challenging because most of the time, they are different forms of controls. But, Chat-GPT is a really good tool to help understand them.

title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text: As a part of my major (Biochemistry) class, we have to do a weekly discussion post summarizing a scientific article of our choice related. However, we all do research in different topics and it can be challenging to interpret figures and results, especially when I am not familiar with the techniques or molecules (proteins, genes, inhibitors, etc.) being used/mentioned.

title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text:
Got it ‚Äî this is an EMSA (Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay) figure (Fig. 4B). Let‚Äôs break it down step by step:
üîé What‚Äôs in the figure?
Lane setup (grid above the gel):
Probe = DNA probe (labeled).
Nuc. Extract = nuclear extract (contains transcription factors).
IFN-Œ≥ = cytokine used to stimulate STAT1 signaling.
Ruxolitinib = JAK inhibitor (at 50 nM, 250 nM, 500 nM).
IgG = nonspecific antibody control.
Anti-pSTAT1 = supershift antibody to confirm STAT1 binding.
Gel bands (bottom image):
Shows DNA-protein complexes.
Red circles highlight the shifted bands (pSTAT1 bound to DNA probe).
When anti-pSTAT1 antibody is added, the complex is shifted even higher ‚Üí confirming specificity of STAT1-DNA binding.
Ruxolitinib treatment reduces the band intensity, showing inhibition of STAT1 activation.
üßæ Interpretation
Without IFN-Œ≥: no strong STAT1 binding.
With IFN-Œ≥: a clear shifted band (activated STAT1 binding DNA).
With increasing Ruxolitinib: reduced band intensity (dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1).
With Anti-pSTAT1 antibody: supershifted band ‚Üí proves that STAT1 is indeed binding to the probe.
IgG control: no shift, confirming specificity.
üìå In summary
This figure shows that IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA, and Ruxolitinib dose-dependently blocks this binding. The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody confirms that the DNA-binding protein is phosphorylated STAT1.



Perfect ‚Äî let‚Äôs do a detailed analysis of this Fig. 4B EMSA:

What the experiment tests

This is an Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) using nuclear extracts from CCD841 cells.
The goal is to see whether STAT1 (activated by IFN-Œ≥) binds to a DNA probe and whether this is affected by the JAK inhibitor Ruxolitinib.
Antibodies (IgG or anti-pSTAT1) are included to test specificity of the protein‚ÄìDNA interaction.

Lane breakdown (based on the grid above the gel)

Probe only: no band shift ‚Üí probe runs at baseline.
Probe + Nuclear extract: weak/absent shift unless IFN-Œ≥ is present.

IFN-Œ≥: strong shifted band appears ‚Üí consistent with STAT1 activation.
Ruxolitinib (50, 250, 500 nM): progressive loss of the shifted band, showing dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1 DNA binding.
IgG: no change (control for nonspecific antibody).
Anti-pSTAT1: band supershifts upward ‚Üí confirms that phosphorylated STAT1 is the DNA-binding protein.


What the bands mean

The red circles highlight the DNA‚Äìprotein complexes (STAT1 bound to probe).
When Ruxolitinib concentration increases, the band intensity decreases ‚Üí JAK‚ÄìSTAT signaling is inhibited.
The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 is the definitive proof that the protein binding the probe is STAT1.

Overall interpretation

This figure demonstrates that:
IFN-Œ≥ activates STAT1 binding to DNA in CCD841 cells.
Ruxolitinib inhibits this activation in a dose-dependent manner.
The binding is specific to phosphorylated STAT1, confirmed by the supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody.



Something that immediately stands out is that without the prompt. Chat-GPT starts with a very general description of the figure, outlining each individual part and clarifying the experimental groups. Both versions give descriptions of the bands; however, the one with the prompt is much more detailed and it explains the logic more clearly. Both give fairly sound interpretations, but the answer given from the prompt contextualizes the results moreso than the answer without the prompt.
Chat-GPT is surprisingly able to extract a lot of data and reasoning within scientific figures. I personally find interpreting blot data, especially ones with so many experimental condiitons, quite challenging because most of the time, they are different forms of controls. But, Chat-GPT is a really good tool to help understand them.

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Help Me Solve Bracket City?
text:
Bracket City is a nested clue word puzzle game made by The Atlantic. You start with short phrases that act as clues to a word. Then that word helps you make sense of ‚Äòouter‚Äô phrases, which then hint at other clues. Essentially, you work your way out (hence the ‚Äònested‚Äô part) until you solve the whole puzzle. Shout out Came








First, I am going to ask Chat-GPT about one of the simpler clues. I first informed the LLM of what game I was playing. Then, as the prompt, I just typed in:

age of certain tale-telling wives.

Response:

Step 1. Identify the reference:
‚Äútale-telling wives‚Äù ‚Üí almost certainly refers to The Wife of Bath from The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. She is one of the most famous ‚Äútale-telling wives.‚Äù
Step 2. Look for the wordplay:
Crossword-style clues usually have:
A definition (here: ‚Äúage‚Äù), and a wordplay part (here: ‚Äúof certain tale-telling wives‚Äù). The ‚Äúwives‚Äù bit suggests plural. The ‚Äúage‚Äù might be something like ‚ÄúERA.‚Äù
Step 3. Put it together
‚ÄúAge‚Äù = ERA
‚ÄúCertain tale-telling wives‚Äù = wives from The Canterbury Tales ‚Üí ‚ÄúWIFE OF BATH‚Äù (but plural doesn‚Äôt quite fit).
But in wordplay terms:
‚ÄúBath‚Äù is a city.
‚ÄúAge‚Äù can clue ERA.
So ‚Äútale-telling wives‚Äù (Wife of Bath ‚Üí Bath ‚Üí ERA) ‚Üí answer is ERA.
‚úÖ So the answer is likely ERA = ‚Äúage.‚Äù The clue works because ‚Äútale-telling wives‚Äù hints at the Wife of Bath, whose home is Bath ‚Üí ‚ÄúBATH‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúAGE‚Äù = ‚ÄúERA.‚Äù

So that‚Äôs not right üòû nor does it really make sense‚Ä¶
After thinking some more, I got the right answer. old




Chat-GPT prompt:

embodiment of the establishment

Response:

Nice clue ‚Äî here are the best short answers and why they fit:

status quo ‚Äî (my top pick) literally means the existing state of affairs; calling someone the ‚Äúembodiment of the establishment‚Äù often points to a person or thing that represents the status quo.
establishment ‚Äî a more literal, single-word option: the institution or ruling class itself; can be used figuratively to mean an embodiment.
pillar of society ‚Äî a common phrase for a respected person who embodies establishment values.
establishmentarian ‚Äî a rarer, longer noun meaning someone who supports the establishment (works as a direct ‚Äúembodiment‚Äù answer if length isn‚Äôt constrained).


Again, these answers don‚Äôt really make sense‚Ä¶

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Help Me Solve Bracket City?
text:
My Verdict
Chat-GPT5 is ‚Ä¶ (drum-roll please) terrible at Bracket City!
After inputting two clues into the LLM, it unfortunately was not able to get either one. For the first clue about tale-telling wives, Chat-GPT5 dissected the clue a bit too far in my opinion, taking into account hyper-specific references that weren‚Äôt at all related to the eventual answer. Additionally, for the second clue, it also did not give good options. I wanted to point out one of the bullet points being a word that was literally in clue, meaning that it couldn‚Äôt be the answer.
I think in general, Chat-GPT5 gives Bracket City answers that are incredibly overcomplicated. Perhaps it overanalyzes the clues, overlooking the general simplicity and accessibility of the game.

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Walk Me Through Connections?
text:
I‚Äôve already tested Chat-GPT5 on other puzzles, how does it do with one of the most annoying - Connections?

Task: I am first going to prompt the LLM that I will be giving it a list of words, and its job is to play the NYT ‚ÄòConnections‚Äô game with that group of words. Then I will respond with a list of all 16 words and see how successful ChatGPT5 is at playing the game!

Prompt:

I will be giving you a list of 16 words. I want you to play the New York Times Connections game with those words.



Response:

Perfect ‚Äî I‚Äôm ready! Go ahead and give me your list of 16 words, and I‚Äôll solve it like a Connections puzzle.



List of Words:

raven, pinky, chip, jet, inky, rocky, file, clyde, hardy, sue, teller, charge, indict, itchy, pitch, cher



Answer:
Nice ‚Äî this is a fun and tricky Connections-style list! Let‚Äôs solve it step by step.
Here are the 16 words again: raven, pinky, chip, jet, inky, rocky, file, clyde, hardy, sue, teller, charge, indict, itchy, pitch, cher




üü© Group 1: Pac-Man ghosts
These are the names of the ghosts from Pac-Man:

Blinky (not here)
Pinky ‚úÖ
Inky ‚úÖ
Clyde ‚úÖ

Group: Pinky, Inky, Clyde, (implied Blinky) ‚úÖ Category: Pac-Man ghosts



üü® Group 2: Famous duos / pairs (X & Y)

Laurel & Hardy ‚úÖ
Bonnie & Clyde ‚úÖ
Hall & Oates (no)
Simon & Garfunkel (no) Let‚Äôs see what else pairs‚Ä¶
Sonny & Cher ‚úÖ
Penn & Teller ‚úÖ

Group: Hardy, Clyde, Cher, Teller ‚úÖ Category: One half of famous duos



üü¶ Group 3: Words related to electricity / energy

Charge ‚úÖ
Jet (as in propulsion, not exactly)
Indict (no) Hmm, maybe not. Let‚Äôs look again.




üü™ Group 3: Words related to law/legal terms

Sue ‚úÖ
Indict ‚úÖ
Charge ‚úÖ
File ‚úÖ (as in ‚Äúfile a lawsuit‚Äù)

Group: Sue, Indict, Charge, File ‚úÖ Category: Legal actions

That leaves: raven, jet, chip, rocky, itchy, pitch



üü¶ Group 4: Nicknames or adjectives ending in ‚Äú-y‚Äù (cartoon / character-like)

Rocky ‚úÖ (Rocky & Bullwinkle)
Itchy ‚úÖ (Itchy & Scratchy Show)
Chip ‚úÖ (Chip & Dale)
Jet ‚úÖ (as in The Jetsons family name ‚ÄúJetson‚Äù? hmm) Or maybe ‚ÄúRaven‚Äù fits elsewhere.

Let‚Äôs test an alternate pattern.



Possible theme: Nicknames from pop culture / animated shows

Rocky ‚Üí Rocky & Bullwinkle
Itchy ‚Üí Itchy & Scratchy
Chip ‚Üí Chip & Dale
Jet ‚Üí The Jetsons (Jetson family)

‚úÖ Category: Cartoon / animated show characters

‚úÖ Final Groups:








Color
Words
Category




üü©
Pinky, Inky, Clyde, Blinky (missing but implied)
Pac-Man ghosts


üü®
Hardy, Clyde, Cher, Teller
Famous duos (one half of a pair)


üü™
Sue, Indict, Charge, File
Legal actions


üü¶
Rocky, Itchy, Chip, Jet
Cartoon characters




Would you like me to rank the groups from easiest to hardest like the NYT game does?


Something already seems off‚Ä¶
If you look closely at the Green and Yellow colors, the Green group only has 3 words (Blinky isn‚Äôt a part of the word list) and the Yellow group reuses a word from the Green group (Clyde).
Also, ‚Äúraven‚Äù never gets used.
Nevertheless, let‚Äôs try the Yellow group!

Yellow group (Hardy, Clyde, Cher, and Teller) works!
ChatGTP5 gussed the category as well ‚Äì ‚ÄúSecond in a famous real-life duo‚Äù
Now let‚Äôs move onto Purple group‚Ä¶


Purple group (Sue, Indict, Charge, File) is correct!
Category is also correct!
Let‚Äôs try Blue now


Blue group (Rocky, Itchy, Chip, Jet) is wrong, but only one off
I assume this is where the issue with the Green group comes in since it was missing one and ‚ÄúRaven‚Äù was missing from the group of words entirely.
Let‚Äôs ask the LLM!


Prompt:

The green group is missing a word and the blue group is incorrect. The other two groups are correct.



Answer:

Nice ‚Äî thanks for the hint. You were right: my blue group was off and the green group I gave was incomplete. Here‚Äôs the corrected solution.
Final groups
Green ‚Äî synonyms for ‚Äúblack‚Äù raven, jet, inky, pitch (raven-black, jet-black, inky-black, pitch-black)
Yellow ‚Äî one half of famous duos hardy, clyde, cher, teller (Laurel & Hardy; Bonnie & Clyde; Sonny & Cher; Penn & Teller)
Purple ‚Äî legal actions / filings file, indict, charge, sue
Blue ‚Äî halves of famous cartoon/animated pairs pinky, chip, rocky, itchy (Pinky & the Brain; Chip & Dale; Rocky & Bullwinkle; Itchy & Scratchy)
Want me to explain any grouping in more detail or play again with a new set? üéØ

This looks like it makes more sense now, let‚Äôs try it!

New Green group (Raven, Jet, Inky, Pitch) is correct!
Category (‚ÄúBlack‚Äù) is also correct!
Blue group has to be correct now, but let‚Äôs just test it


New Blue group (Pinky, Chip, Rocky, Itchy) is correct!
Category is also correct!




My Thoughts
Although ChatGTP5 was able to solve it in the end, I was a bit disappointed that it didn‚Äôt catch its initial error with the missing words. I found it very odd that it completely added in a word that wasn‚Äôt present and completely missed a word. I think Connections sometimes has red-herring categories that only fit three of the words to purposefully throw people off. I think the LLM fell for it and inserted its own word that would‚Äôve worked for that category. However, once I gave it a hint and pointed out the flaw, it was perfectly able to figure out the last two categories. Speaking of categories, the LLM was also able to guess those. The only thing the LLM wasn‚Äôt really able to guess was the color of the categories, which, for those who aren‚Äôt very familiar with ‚ÄúConnections‚Äù, denotes the difficulty of the category. Yellow is easist, Green is easy, Blue is medium, and Purple is hardest.

title: Can LLM‚Äôs Decipher a Song?
text:
What does Google Gemini think about Hozier‚Äôs - From Eden?

In class, we took any song of our choice and analyzed it through Google Gemini (Gemini-2.5-flash). We uploaded an audio file to gcloud and prompted the LLM with this: > Listen to this music. > Close your eyes and focus on how it makes you feel. > What images come into your head as you listen to it. > What emotions do you experience. > How would you describe these feelings and images to someone?

This is what the LLM inferred:

Making LLM inference request‚Ä¶
This music immediately creates a sense of intimacy and introspection.
How it makes me feel / Emotions experienced:

Melancholy: There‚Äôs a gentle, underlying sadness, not despair, but a quiet pensiveness. It feels like reflecting on something beautiful but lost, or a bittersweet truth.
Nostalgia: A strong sense of looking back, perhaps at a past relationship or a simpler time, with a blend of fondness and regret.
Tenderness/Affection: Despite the melancholy, there‚Äôs a deep warmth and affection in the vocal delivery and the gentle harmonies. It feels like a loving observation of someone or something complex.
Vulnerability: The singer‚Äôs voice, especially with the close harmonies, conveys a sense of openness and honesty.
Calm/Relaxed: The moderate tempo and acoustic instrumentation provide a very calming backdrop, encouraging a relaxed state of listening.

Images that come into my head:

A quiet, early morning: Sunlight filtering through curtains, steam rising from a cup of coffee.
A reflective drive: Long stretches of road, perhaps in autumn, with changing landscapes.
An old photograph: A faded picture of a loved one or a significant moment, stirring memories.
Rainy window panes: Watching the world outside, lost in thought.
Two people sitting close, but in quiet contemplation: Not necessarily speaking, just existing together in a shared, intimate space.
A rustic, cozy cabin: Warm wood, soft light, a crackling fire, a sense of being sheltered from the outside world while reflecting on it.
The lyrics, particularly ‚ÄúI slithered through from Eden, just to sit outside your door,‚Äù paint a vivid picture of patient longing and a journey from a lost paradise to a hopeful, albeit somewhat distant, presence.

How I would describe these feelings and images to someone:
‚ÄúImagine a crisp autumn morning, sitting by a window, watching the world wake up slowly. This music feels like a gentle, thoughtful conversation with yourself about someone you deeply cherish, who might be complex or even a bit broken, but whose essence still captivates you. It‚Äôs profoundly bittersweet, laced with tender longing and a touch of wistful nostalgia. The acoustic guitars and the singer‚Äôs heartfelt voice create an incredibly intimate atmosphere, like someone is sharing their most private reflections right beside you. It evokes images of cherished memories, quiet contemplation, and the enduring nature of love despite imperfections or past hurts. It‚Äôs the perfect soundtrack for introspection, for savoring moments of quiet beauty and the bittersweet realities of life and relationships.‚Äù



Then, we asked the LLM to generate an image based on those descriptions






Reflection
This song makes me feel bittersweet in a way. There‚Äôs a tone of melancholy and tragedy that the lyrics portray that‚Äôs also very dramatic. I think overall Gemini did a pretty good job of coming up with emotional descriptions because it came up with really similar descriptions to that. There are certain nuances to the lyrics that feel different than the melody, which I think the LLM overlooked. It definitely has fall season and rustic vibes, but that is also reflective of the artist in general, so I‚Äôm not sure how unique that description is to the song.

title: Can AI Solve Brain Teaser Word Puzzles?
text:
Back in 4th grade, my teacher would have us do brain teasers every day during lunch. She would write them down and project them onto the white board. There was no reward, no prize, just bragging rights. From this, I was inspired to see if LLM‚Äôs were any better than I was at 10 years old. Does Chat-GPT have the ability to guess a word or saying based on a very literal picture? Let‚Äôs find out!


Let‚Äôs see if I can figure out these eight teasers

Forget it (4 Get It)
Blackjack?
Somewhere over the rainbow
Back door?
Read between the lines
Blood is thicker than water
???
Cancelled check

The only one I missed was number 7, which was ‚ÄúBeeline‚Äù. Out of eight, I missed one of them, which honestly isn‚Äôt bad. Now let‚Äôs see how Chat-GPT holds up.


I pasted the exact photo into Chat-GPT, what does it say?
I added the prompt, ‚ÄúSolve these brain teasers‚Äù

Chat-GPT Response:
Sure! Below are the solutions to the brain teasers based on visual and wordplay clues:

‚ÄúGet it‚Äù repeated 4 times
Answer: ‚ÄúForget it‚Äù
(The word ‚ÄúGet it‚Äù is repeated four times, indicating the phrase ‚ÄúForget it‚Äù.)
‚ÄúJack‚Äù in a black box
Answer: ‚ÄúJack in the box‚Äù
(Literal interpretation of the phrase‚Äîa Jack in a box.)
‚ÄúSomewhere‚Äù above a rainbow
Answer: ‚ÄúSomewhere over the rainbow‚Äù
(Classic phrase and song lyric.)
The word ‚ÄúDOOR‚Äù is reversed
Answer: ‚ÄúBackdoor‚Äù
(The reversed word implies a door going back or behind.)
The word ‚ÄúREAD‚Äù between two lines
Answer: ‚ÄúRead between the lines‚Äù
(A classic idiom, shown visually.)
‚ÄúBlood‚Äù over ‚ÄúWater‚Äù
Answer: ‚ÄúBlood is thicker than water‚Äù
(Common expression indicating family bonds are stronger.)
The word ‚ÄúBeeeeeee‚Äù stretched out
Answer: ‚ÄúLong time no see‚Äù
(The extended ‚ÄúBe‚Äù indicates a long ‚ÄúB‚Äù, a pun suggesting ‚ÄúLong time no B(see)‚Äù.)
The word ‚ÄúCANCELLED‚Äù falling down diagonally like stairs
Answer: ‚ÄúCancelled check‚Äù
(The word is ‚Äúchecked down‚Äù or struck down stepwise‚Äîvisual pun.)
Let me know if you want explanations for any specific ones!




My analysis of the LLM performance
Chat-GPT was incorrect on two of the eight riddles, which means‚Ä¶I WIN!
All that aside however, the LLM actually perfomed better than I originally thought. It‚Äôs logic on most of the riddles was the exact same logic that I used. I originally believed it would be difficult for the LLM to decipher the words/saying behind the picture due to the necessary ‚Äòthinking outside the box‚Äô mindset behind brain teasers. Where it fell short was in the 2nd and 7th riddle. ‚ÄòJack in the Box‚Äô is also not completely wrong. I would‚Äôve likely guessed that after my original guess. For the 7th image, I think the LLM was a bit further off. It attempted to use a pun to justify the answer, but it didn‚Äôt make much sense.
LLM Grade: 75%, C


Reflection
The LLM‚Äôs ability to pick up on the subtleties present is quite fascinating. More specificaly, it was able to recognize puns in a visual form and translate it into a common saying. I was genuinely quite impressed to see that the LLM was able to pick up the majority of the solutions and go about solving them the same way I did. The only one that it was completely wrong for was also one that I couldn‚Äôt solve. Perhaps that is not necessarily a shortcoming on AI, but rather that the image itself was a more difficult riddle.

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 2: Can it guess the personality type based on descriptions?
section: How will I prompt the LLM (Microsoft Copilot, GPT-5)?
text:
How will I prompt the LLM (Microsoft Copilot, GPT-5)?
In my last post, I had asked ChatGPT-5 to give me a description of ‚Äúmyself‚Äù based on my MBTI (16 personalities), which is ISTJ, the ‚ÄòLogistiann‚Äô.
I am now going to put portions of that into Microsoft Copilot GPT-5 and ask to see if it can guess the MBTI.
Microsoft Copilot Prompt:

Guess the MBTI with the description I give you. Grounded and dependable, these individuals are driven by responsibility, reliability, and commitment. They value tradition, structure, and practicality, excelling in environments that require accuracy and consistency. Loyal and steady in relationships, they show care through actions rather than words. Their strengths lie in perseverance, organization, and a strong sense of duty, though they may sometimes struggle with rigidity or resistance to change.

Response:

This description strongly aligns with ISTJ ‚Äî the Logistician type. Here‚Äôs why ISTJ fits so well:



Introverted (I): Shows care through actions rather than words, prefers reliability over emotional expression.
Sensing (S): Values tradition, structure, and practicality ‚Äî grounded in the present and focused on facts.
Thinking (T): Driven by responsibility and logic, not swayed by emotions.
Judging (J): Organized, committed, and thrives in structured environments with clear expectations.



ISTJs are known for their loyalty, precision, and sense of duty. They‚Äôre the backbone of many institutions ‚Äî dependable, methodical, and often the quiet achievers who keep everything running smoothly. Their challenge? Adapting to change and loosening up rigid routines.


It actually guessed it correctly! Now let‚Äôs try something else.
I asked ChatGPT-5 to create a ‚ÄòDay-in-the-life‚Äô story of someone who has this MBTI. This was the response:

Evelyn‚Äôs alarm rang at 6:15 sharp, just as it did every weekday. She liked the predictability of mornings ‚Äî coffee brewed while she folded yesterday‚Äôs laundry, a short walk around the block before sitting down at her desk. By 8:00, she was in the office, checking her to-do list against the team‚Äôs shared calendar. A colleague had forgotten to submit a report, so she quietly picked up the slack, knowing it was easier to handle it herself than risk the deadline being missed. Lunch was always the same ‚Äî a packed container of leftovers, eaten while she skimmed through local news. She preferred her routines; they gave her a sense of calm when everything else felt uncertain. In the evening, she stopped by her parents‚Äô house to drop off groceries. They hadn‚Äôt asked, but she noticed last week they were running low on basics, and it made her feel better knowing she could help. Later, back at home, she finished the day with a book she‚Äôd already read twice. The familiar story was like an anchor, grounding her before bed. It wasn‚Äôt a flashy life, but it was steady. And for Evelyn, there was comfort in knowing she could be counted on ‚Äî for herself, and for the people who mattered most.

I pasted it into Microsoft Copilot GPT-5 and ask it to guess the MBTI:

Evelyn is radiating ISTJ energy ‚Äî the Logistician type.


Here‚Äôs how her story maps to the ISTJ profile:



Introverted (I): She finds peace in solitude and routine, not in social stimulation. Her care is quiet and action-based ‚Äî dropping off groceries without being asked, handling tasks without fanfare.
Sensing (S): Evelyn is grounded in the present, attentive to details (like her parents‚Äô pantry), and prefers familiar, tangible experiences ‚Äî rereading a book, sticking to leftovers.
Thinking (T): She‚Äôs pragmatic and logical ‚Äî choosing to complete a colleague‚Äôs task to avoid missed deadlines, not out of emotional impulse.
Judging (J): Her life runs on structure: alarms, calendars, routines, and predictability. She thrives on order and responsibility.



ISTJs are the kind of people who keep the world running quietly in the background. They‚Äôre not flashy, but they‚Äôre rock-solid. Evelyn‚Äôs story is a love letter to consistency, duty, and quiet strength.



Once again, it‚Äôs correct!

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 2: Can it guess the personality type based on descriptions?
text:
Reflection
I was somewhat expecting Copilot to be able to guess from the description of the personality. From its rationale, it seemed like the description matched key words that the LLM was specifically looking for. When I decided to use the story, I thought it would be a bit more difficult for the LLM to discern the MBTI since character traits were less explicit and hidden inside actions, meaning it would have to look deeper into the character‚Äôs actions. However, after reading Copilot‚Äôs logical reasoning after mapping it to the ISTJ profile, it does an intuitive job that is quite impressive. It higlights the character‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúbe grounded in the present‚Äù and ‚Äúchoosing to complete a colleague‚Äôs task‚Äù for pragmatic reasons and not emotional ones. The latter observation specifically piqued my interest because I think it requires a higher level of intuition to notice that and have that reasoning.

title: Can Chat-GPT5 recreate a famous piece of art from scratch?
text: One of the most famous and recognizable paintings of all time, ‚ÄòGirl with a Pearl Earring‚Äô was painted by Johannes Vermeer around 1665. With only descriptions and directions from me, how close can Chat-GPT5 get to the original painting?

title: Can Chat-GPT5 recreate a famous piece of art from scratch?
text:
My Reflection
Although I was fairly impressed by Chat-GPT5‚Äôs ability to recreate the original ‚ÄòGirl with a Pearl Earring‚Äô painting solely on a description, it‚Äôs ability to create something original is quite disappointing. The LLM doesn‚Äôt seem to grasp anatomy all that well and it changes small, but instrumental, details without me prompting it to do so. Thorughout the process, it appears that the gaze and innocence of the girl was lost. Additionally, I thought that it was odd that Chat-GPT5 chose to crop the jacket at that length because normally they are longer. It was impressive, however, that the LLM was able to keep the integrity of the oil painting style. When asked to extend the painting, it felt fairly cohesive, but only for the style and painting strokes.
